title.narrative: Life-Saving Emergency Trauma Care Services to Conflict-Affected People in Paktika Province through Sharana Provincial Hospital (PH) and Janikhel FATP

description.narrative: International Medical Corps proposes to strengthen the emergency health and trauma care services in Paktika Province. The proposed program will increase access to quality emergency trauma care services through supporting a newly constructed Emergency Room (ER) in Sharana PH, reactivating and equipping the second Operating Theatre (OT) of the hospital, providing mobile trauma services and the establishing a First Aid Trauma Post (FATP) in Janikhel District. The proposed intervention will primarily serve the conflict-affected population in Sharana, Janikhel and Wazakhwa districts of Paktika. International Medical Corps will provide emergency medical supplies and medical equipment to the ER and OT of the hospital, as well as provide one standard ambulance equipped and supplied with all necessary items to provide first aid and basic life support for the most conflict-affected areas. International Medical Corps will also provide ten in-patient beds to the surgical ward of the hospital to be prepared for admitting more patients during mass casualties. International Medical Corps will also enhance the emergency services of the hospital by recruiting six professional nurses and six support staff who will provide crucial assistance to the ER, OT and mobile trauma services. Additionally, International Medical Corps will provide Mass Casualty Management (MCM) training to senior health staff, management and administrative staff of the hospital as well as related staff from the PPHD, private sector and local authorities to strengthen immediate care and the referral system, which will help the hospital to provide adequate and timely responses and care without unacceptable mortality and/or morbidity. International Medical Corps will also provide MCM simulation exercises to assess the existing capacity of the hospital in terms of mass casualty management, identify gaps for improvement, and mobilize local resources. Furthermore, International Medical Corps will construct a proper Triage Area for mass casualties, which will otherwise be used as a waiting area by patient attendants. International Medical Corps will also coordinate with WHO and PPHD to preposition standard Trauma Care Kits as a reliable, standardized, affordable and quickly available source of the essential medicines and medical supplies needed urgently in mass casualties
